document.text: Y. W. C. A. Report. The regular meeting of the board of directors of the Young Womens Chris tian Association was held in the chapel of the Presbyterian Committee of Pub lication, Miss Katharine H. Hawes pre siding. There was a full attendance and much enthusiasm expressed over the progress of the work. A full financial statement will be given to the public in January, and in the mean while it was reported that the new hoarding home at 108 West Carey street is rapidly nearing completion, and will be ready for use by March 1  that the administration building to be erected at 6 North Fifth street has been unavoidably delayed by minor legal complications, but it is expected that ground wjll be broken before Jan uary 1 . .

document.text: Thomas E. Caldwell was elected worshipful master of Marshall Lodge 39, A .F  A.M. at its meeting December 28. Other officers elect ed were E. Lewis McCutcheon, senior war den J.T . Sublett, junior warden W .T. Big-bie, treasurer C. Allen Evans, secretary H. A. Harvey, senior deacon J.R . Swartz, junior deacon J.W . Scott, tiler P. L. Hawes, chaplain. Mr Caldwell is an Appomattox native, and! the broither-in-law of Miss Flora Belle Williams, of the local school faculty. This is his third year as worshipful master.

document.text: The time has come, the Wal rus said, To talk of many, things-- Of shoesof shipsof sealing wax Of cabbages anglings.   I What family name is most prevalent in Appomattox coun ty? Thats one for you. Ac cording to the list of eligible- voters for 1932, just printed this week by the Times-Vir- ginian, there are 47 Fergusons registered and 46 Martins. Other leaders are 43 Smith 31 Caldwells 31 Moores 29 Colemans, and 22 Marshalls and 31 Harveys.    Didya know that an aunt of Albert Payson Terhyne, the fa mous story writer, lives in Ap pomattox county? And didya know that H. B. Hawes has written a delightful story call ed Daughter of Blood?    To S. C. Ranson, of Ever green, goes the distinction of purchasing the first car from the new Pulliam and Martin Motor Co., here. His picture, in the new car, will be taken at the old Court House, and published in the Ford News, a trade journal going all over the world, according to Herbert Pulliam.    Didya know that R. C. Wag ner, of Appomattox, served 14 years as a Y. M. C. A. physical director? His pride now is his fish pond. He has the Mystic Knights of the SeaThe King Fish, Andy, Brother Crawford, Madam Queen, ,etc., cavorting in said pond.

document.text: The family of Mrs. Homer Reynolds enjoyed a reunion Sun day at the home of her son, Clyde H. Reynolds, Richmond! All eight of her children and families were present.    Miss Debbie Ford, of Lynch burg, is spending this week with her grandmother, Mrs. Clara Mitchell.    Mrs. Lora Lawson Coleman, of Lynchburg, and son, Hawes Cole man, of Rustburg, were guests Sunday of Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Smith. 9 0 0 Miss Annie Laura Moore has returned to her home in Crewe after spending thee weeks in the home of her brother, R. c. Moore.    Mrs. Stella R. St. Clair spent the week with her husband, Pfc. William E. St Clair, who is stat ioned at Ft. Sheridan, 111.    Visitors in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Franklin this week were Mr. and Mrs. Billy Ingram and children, of Wash ington, D. C., also Mrs. Frank lins sister, Mrs. Doris Hack- worth, of Tampa, Fla.    Sunday night guests in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Elliott, Appomattox, were Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Booker and Scottle, of Prospect also, Mr. and Mrs. Curtis McKay and two daughters of Farmville.    Sunday guests in the home of Mr. and Mrs. E. H. Johnson were Mrs. Sallie R. Johnson, Farm ville Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Johnson, and little Karen ,of Richmond Mr. and Mrs. Lawr ence Johnson, Pamplin Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Burrell and Steve Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Elliott and two children, of Ap pomattox.    Mr. and Mrs. William S. Moses of Roanoke, were week end visi tors at the home of Mrs. Don Moses. Their daughter, Susan, spent the week of June 28 to July 4th here visiting her grand mother, aunt, and cousins.    . Sandra Harvey recently took a trip to Natural Bridge, Dixie Caverns, and Roanoke. She and other friends spent the night at Mountain Cave Lake Park, near Natural Bridge.   0 Mrs. Alpha Fleetwood left Wednesday for her home in Phi ladelphia after spending a week here with her mother, Mrs. Al pha Higginbotham. 0 0 0 Chief R. A. Elliott and daugh ter, Suzanne, and Miss CeceUa Smith, of Charleston Heights, Charleston, S.C., will spend this week end with Mrs. Alpha Higg inbotham. 0 0 0 Mrs. C. S. Booth will leave today for Arlington, where she will spend several days with her daughter, Mrs. K. H. Percall. Mr. Booth will be in Richmond on a business trip.

document.text: The executive board of the United Mineworkers, in session in Indianapo lis, adopted a resolution recognizing the steel strike and pledging support to the Amalgamated Association. Mrs. Charles Gallagher, of New York, was frightened by a high w in! on the Y ork river, and became para lyzed and died. Josiah Johnson Hawes, of Boston, said to be the oldest photographer in the world, died in New Hampshire, aged 94 years. Peter Short, of Sussex county, Del., was seriously scalded while threshing wheat near Laurel, Del. It is believed in Philadelphia that fatal defects have been found in the  Ripper bill for that city. James H. Jones, of Caroline county, Va., was dangerously stabbed by Camp bell . Madison. Mrs. Harriet Vinson, mother of Colonel Capron, died in Clarke county, Va.. aged 84 years. Miss Effie Richey, aged 30 years, a bookkeeper, killed herself at Fort Wayne, Ind. Frank Howell tried to kill his parents near Linden, N. J. General Rufus Neely died at Bolivar, Tenn.. aged 93 years. Andrew Hamilton was drowned at Grand View, Va. The steamer Norfolk, in the Roads, was burned to the waters edge, involv ing a loss of 50,000. She was the handsomest steamer used as a transfer boat between Sewells Point and Old Point Comfort. A report received at Washington from Admiral Kempff tells of the bit ing off of a leg ofa quartermaster of the Annapolis by a shark while bath ing at Iloilo. In New York John Seager has sued C. C. Worthington, a millionaire pump manufacturer, for 100,000 for alleged alienation of the affections of his wife. The bituminous coal combine has

document.text: The Daughter of the Blood has been issued by The Four Seas Company, of Boston in a first edition of 2,000 copies. The book is bound in full cloth, and has illustrations and maps. Dr. Asia Watkins, professor of literature, Hampden-Sidney College, writes of Mr Hawes book, An interesting mixture Scott-like of flaming romance! rnattox and history . . . . t h e alluring might-have-beens of the past, the brooding mysteries of the silent Virginia forests and mountains, rivers and shores and islands. The Daughter of the Blood is the authors ielightful answer to the old easing question about Vir ginia Dare, first-born white American. Critics of the novel partic ularly stress its wholesome- ness, and its historical rich ness. Mr- Hawes is a nephew of the Virginia novelist, Mar ian Harland, and a first cousin to Albert Payson Terhune- -------------- o ------------ Hubbard Funeral

text.snippet: College, writes of Mr <mark>Hawes</mark> book, An interesting mixture

document.text: th. Evington, Mrs. John lorraine Denton, Richmond, and Mrs. George Delphine Cash, Amherst one brother,. Louis T. Gowen, Salem onelhalf brother, Sam Gowen. Rustburg five half sisters. Mrs. Virginia Reynolds, Hridcroft. Mrs. Lilly Holland. Polka. Fla., Mrs. Elsie Krantz, Altavista, and- Mrs. Frances Mason and Mrs. Grane Chenault, both of Lynchburg 48 grandchildren and 81 great-grand children. Funeral sendees were conducted at 2 p.m. Thursday by the Rev. Carl Burger and Jim Critchley at Penuel Baptist Church, with burial in Altavista Memorial Park. Finch and Finch Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements. Joel Wiliam Jack Martin Joel William Jack Martin, 82, died Friday afternoon, Feb. 4, in Lynchburg General Hospital. He was born in Appomattox County, a son of the late Joel Habnéé and Mollie-Wright Martin. He eras a retired merchant, a. member of John W. Ferguson Lodge No. 185,100F, and a member of Liberty Baptist Church. He is survived for his rifo, Maude Ferguson Martin one son, Ottway Martin, Appomattox two daugh ters, Mrs. Thomas C. Watson, Appomattox, and Mrs. Glenn R. Hawes, Lynchburg a brother. Albert Dick Martin, Appomattox three sisters, Mrs. Roland Smith, Mrs. Emmett Day and Mrs. Willie Mayberry, aD of Appomattox nine grandchildren and four great-grand children.  Funeral services rere conducted Sunday at 2 p.m. from Robinson Funeral Home by the Rev. George Kreidel, with burial in Old Herman Cemetery. Robinson Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements. Eugene Booth PHEN1X - Eugene Roach, 80, of Route 1. died accidentally near his home Monday night. Jan. 31. His wife wasthe late Nellie Jennings Roach.-

document.text: State Normal School. Fredericksburg.The hoard of trus tees of the Fredericksburg State Nor mal School has elected the faculty for tie coming session, as follows A. B. Chandler, jr., dean of the school, with duties to be assigned by the president df the school W. N. Hamlet, science and mathematics B. Y. Tynder, edu cation Miss Olive SV. MInman, man ual arts and drawing Miss Frances L. Withers, household arts Miss Vir ginia M. Goolrfck, history Miss Mar garet E. Fraser, music  Miss Cary Graves, physical education Miss Dora Dadmun, English Miss jdary Hawes Tyler, modem languages G. M. Harri son,1 adjunct processor of mathematics superintendent of plant and grounds Miss Virginia Stone, riuper- vlsOr of the training school K. C Moore, agriculture Miss Marion C Forbes, head of the home William 8 Chesley, business manager pr. C Mason Smith, physician. President E. H. Russell presented a full report of the school from the beginning of the school to June 17, 1914, which was received and adopted by the board.

J- j. Wood and the active corps of dels voted teachers. The ninsical programme waBi highly enjoyable, while the exeri rises by the happy children touch-! ed the soft spot iq every heart.  Childrens Day in the Sabbath! Schools is dedicated to the aid ofi some particular church work, tbd object on this occasion being the Congo Mission 0f the Tresbytj rian ohnrch, located in Central Af._ rica. The contributions of the dayl added sixteen dollars to The Lap.! sley Support Fund of the mission. document.text: Radford - John L . Lamp- kin, Jr . of Appomattox will portray the deck hand in the Radford College Theatre pro duction of The King and I on October 31 - November 4 in Porterfield Theatre. I junpkin, a junior theatre major, is the son of M rs. Margaret Lampkin of Route 1. A Rodgers and Hammerstein musical romance, the play tells the story of an English school teacher who is employed to teach western ways to the royal wives, princes and princesses at the court of the King of Siam. The play will be directed by D r. Jam es W . Hawes, chairman of the theatre department.
